title: Eli Manning the trump card for Giants in NFC East race
text:
Eli Manning the trump card for Giants in NFC East race Stephen Edelson , @steveedelsonAPP 8:27 p.m. EDT October 19, 2015 Quarterback Eli Manning gives the Giants a huge advantage in the NFC East this season. (Photo: Getty images) 3 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PHILADELPHIA - The NFC East is there for the taking. 
And in the coming weeks it will be up to Eli Manning to take it. 
Because heading into Monday night’s game at Lincoln Financial Field, Manning, coming off an incredible comeback win over the San Francisco 49ers and playing some of the best football of his career, is by far the best quarterback in the division. 
Not even close. 
And that makes the Giants, already having risen to the top of the division after losing their first two games, the prohibitive favorites to return to the postseason after a three-year hiatus. 
To put it in perspective, Manning’s a two-time Super Bowl MVP, coming off the 27th fourth-quarter comeback victory of his career. 
The Eagles are trotting out quarterback Sam Bradford, who has a 20-33-1 career record as a starter thanks mostly to five injury-plagued seasons in St. Louis. 
The Cowboys are coming off three straight losses with Brandon Weeden at quarterback, with Tony Romo sidelined with a broken collarbone. 
They’re using the bye week to install Matt Cassel as the starter for next Sunday’s game at MetLife Stadium, with Cassel going just 24-33 as a starter since going 10-5 with the Patriots in 2008 when he replaced Tom Brady, landing a big free agent deal from Kansas City. 
And anyone who saw Sunday’s Jets’ game at MetLife Stadium understands that Washington, now 2-4, is in trouble, as quarterback Kirk Cousins continues to struggle. And coach Jay Gruden’s only options behind him are backup Colt McCoy and Robert Griffin III, who he apparently has zero faith in. 
That makes the Giants’ path to their first NFC East title since 2011 pretty straightforward. 
Not only do they have the best quarterback in the division, the lack of any big-time gunslingers for their defense to deal with is huge for a unit that’s already getting thin in the secondary. 
And the Giants should have a better chance against non-divisional foes as well. 
In primetime last Sunday against the 49ers’ Colin Kaepernick, who came within a play of winning the Super Bowl, Manning’s fourth-quarter heroics included a perfectly thrown 12-yard touchdown pass to tight end Larry Donnell, with linebacker NoVorro Bowman draped all over him in the back of the end zone, with 21 seconds to play. 
If Manning can get the Giants out of South Philly with a win — he has a 6-4 record at the Linc over his career — they’ll have a 1 1/2-game lead in the division, with the second-place Cowboys up next. That means by next Sunday the Giants could have the NFC East in a stranglehold. 
All of this is why the Giants shelled out $84-million on a deal for Manning. There’s an opportunity for an immediate return on that investment. 
The clock management woes of the first two weekends are long-forgotten, and he seems so much more comfortable with offensive coordinator Ben McAdoo than he was last season. 
And in his 12th season, Manning has never missed a game due to injury. 
"It’s helped us immensely to be able to have that position solidified.’’ Giants coach Tom Coughlin said, "and have an outstanding player, great leader at that spot over the years to be able to count on that knowing full well that that was going to be done as well as we could do it. Then we would have to deal with all the changes that have happened over the course of time around that position, but because Eli has been there as an anchor and a guy who we can always turn to, it’s been a spot that many times we’ve had to build a football team around. So thank goodness for that.’’ 
So while it’s difficult to quantify exactly what Manning means to the Giants right now, his experience, ability and durability in a weak division could translate into a lot of wins in 2015.
